A law of composition on a set $M$ is a map from $M \times M$ to $M$. It is characterized by the assignment $(a, b) \longmapsto a \cdot b$ for $(a, b) \in M \times M$, and in many cases, the image of a given pair $(a, b)$ is written as a "product" $a \cdot b$ or $ab$.
The image of a function \( f: A 	o B \) is the set of all elements in \( B \) that have at least one corresponding element in \( A \) via the function \( f \).
Does the concept of a/an Law of Composition need to be defined for a definition of a/an Image of Map to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of the Image of a Map involves identifying the set of all outputs in the codomain B that are linked to at least one input in the domain A through a function f. This concept focuses on the relationship between elements of A and their corresponding elements in B as defined by the function f. It does not inherently involve any operations within the set B itself, nor does it require the elements of B to interact with each other according to any specific rule or operation.

On the other hand, a Law of Composition pertains to a rule for combining elements within a single set M to produce another element of the same set. This concept is essential in structures where internal operations are defined, such as in groups, rings, or fields, where the operation (like addition or multiplication) follows certain algebraic rules.

Therefore, the definition and understanding of the Image of a Map do not require the concept of a Law of Composition. The Image of a Map is solely concerned with the mapping from A to B and does not involve the internal structure or operations within the set B, which would be relevant in the context of a Law of Composition.
